pageData.text: Two or more waves can occupy the same space at the same time as described by the <button class='glossary-text'>principle of linear superposition</button>. Depending on how the <button class='glossary-text'>crests</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>troughs</button> of the waves are aligned, they interfere by completely adding together, partially adding together, or completely canceling each other. Standing waves on a string represent a special case of superposition where the <button class='glossary-text'>wavelength</button> is matched to the length of the string. In the Standing Waves on a String lab, you will investigate the conditions for establishing standing waves on a string.

pageData.text: Music is created when artists utilize the properties of waves to create auditory patterns. But the significance of music is different for different people. For some, music lifts their spirits when they feel blue. For others, songs are nostalgic and bring fond memories to mind. For others, the art of creating music to bring joy to others is exhilarating.

In 2013, Canadian astronaut and musician Chris Hadfield went viral when he recorded a cover of David Bowie's "Space Oddity" from the International Space Station. Chris reported that he thought his "Space Oddity" music video from the International Space Station may be the most expensive music video ever created<sup>1</sup>.  In 2015, Chris released his first album, which was also the first album entirely recorded while in orbit<sup>2</sup>. The album is titled “Space Sessions: Songs for a Tin Can”, contains eleven original songs, and is available to listen to for free.

1Space Oddity. (2013). Rare Earth.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KaOC9danxNo

2Daniel, A. (2019). 40 Facts About Music That Really Sing. Best Life.
https://bestlifeonline.com/music-facts/

pageData.desc: Astronaut Chris Hadfield of the Canadian Space Agency (CSA).
pageData.altText: Astronaut Chris Hadfield of the Canadian Space Agency (CSA).

pageData.subTitle: Properties of Waves
pageData.text:
The propagation of an organized disturbance between points in a medium is called a . Waves transfer energy and have properties including , , , , and . or matter waves require the presence of a material medium to transport their energy from one location to another, whereas can travel through a vacuum or outer space. There are two types of mechanical waves:
  • in which the displacement of the particles of the medium move perpendicular to the direction of propagation
  • in which the displacement of the particles in the medium move parallel to the direction of propagation

The period, T, is the time it takes for one complete oscillation of the wave to travel past a point in the medium. Frequency, f, measures the number of oscillations or cycles per unit time and is equal to the reciprocal of the period.

pageData.altText: Equation 1: f equals 1 over T

pageData.text: units: cycles/s = HZ, hertz

The wavelength (λ) is the distance between two corresponding parts of the wave, such as <button class='glossary-text'>crest</button> to crest or <button class='glossary-text'>trough</button> to trough, measured in meters (m). The speed of the wave through the medium is the product of the frequency and the wavelength.

pageData.altText: Equation 2: v equals f times λ

pageData.text: SI unit: m/s

The amplitude is the height, in meters. of the wave above equilibrium (to a crest) or below equilibrium (to a trough) or half the distance measured from crest to trough. The properties of a wave are illustrated in Figure 1.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Diagram of a wave, labeling the wavelength from crest to crest, the amplitude, time, and one oscillation
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram of a wave, labeling the wavelength from crest to crest, the amplitude, time, and one oscillation

pageData.text: Objects, charged particles, and mechanical systems usually have a certain <button class='glossary-text'>frequency</button> at which they tend to vibrate, referred to as the natural frequency. If a small <button class='glossary-text'>amplitude</button> driving force causes another system to vibrate, producing a large amplitude motion, this is the phenomenon of resonance.

pageData.subTitle: Interference of Waves
pageData.text: When two or more waves, which transport energy, occupy the same space at the same time, it is described by the <button class='glossary-text'>principle of linear superposition</button>. Depending on how the <button class='glossary-text'>crests</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>troughs</button> of the waves are aligned, the waves can completely add together, partially add together, or completely cancel each other.

The principle of linear superposition applies to any number of waves, but for simplification, consider two waves coming together. The waves could be sound reaching you simultaneously from two different sources or two pulses traveling toward each other along a string. When the waves meet, they are superimposed, or the amplitudes of the individual waves add together momentarily. Then each wave or pulse continues traveling as if they had never encountered each other.

pageData.question: The image shows a sine wave. The units of y are meters (m), and the units of x are meters (m).  What is the amplitude of this wave?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The amplitude is the height, in meters, of the wave above equilibrium (to a crest) or below equilibrium (to a trough) or half the distance measured from crest to trough.

imageData.desc: A graph with an x axis from –2 to 5, and a y axis from –2 to 2. A sine wave oscillates along the x axis with the crest of each wave at y equals 2, and the trough of each wave at y equals –2.
imageData.altText: A graph with an x axis from –2 to 5, and a y axis from –2 to 2. A sine wave oscillates along the x axis with the crest of each wave at y equals 2, and the trough of each wave at y equals –2.

pageData.question: The image shows a sine wave. The units of y are meters (m), and the units of x are meters (m).  What is the wavelength of this wave?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The wavelength (λ) is the distance between two corresponding parts of the wave, such as crest to crest or trough to trough, measured in meters (m).

imageData.desc: A graph with an x axis from –2 to 5, and a y axis from –2 to 2. A sine wave oscillates along the x axis with the crest of each wave at y equals 2, and the trough of each wave at y equals –2.
imageData.altText: A graph with an x axis from –2 to 5, and a y axis from –2 to 2. A sine wave oscillates along the x axis with the crest of each wave at y equals 2, and the trough of each wave at y equals –2.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The amplitude is the height, in meters. of the wave above equilibrium (to a crest) or below equilibrium (to a trough) or half the distance measured from crest to trough. The properties of a wave are illustrated in Figure 1.

img.alt: Figure 1: Diagram of a wave, labeling the wavelength from crest to crest, the amplitude, time, and one oscillation

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The amplitude is the height, in meters. of the wave above equilibrium (to a crest) or below equilibrium (to a trough) or half the distance measured from crest to trough. The properties of a wave are illustrated in Figure 1.

img.alt: Figure 1: Diagram of a wave, labeling the wavelength from crest to crest, the amplitude, time, and one oscillation

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Constructive interference</button>: If the two waves are in phase—<button class='glossary-text'>crests</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>troughs</button> occur at the same points—constructive interference occurs when the waves come together. This means that their oscillations at a given point are in the same direction and the resulting <button class='glossary-text'>amplitude</button> at that point will be larger than the amplitude of an individual wave. For two waves of equal amplitude interfering constructively, the resulting amplitude is twice as large as the amplitude of an individual wave. Constructive interference produces waves with an increased amplitude (see Figure 2).

<button class='glossary-text'>Destructive interference</button>: In destructive interference (see Figure 2), the two waves come together and are aligned so they completely cancel each other out. When two waves interfere destructively, the crest of one wave and the trough of the other wave meet and their amplitudes add up to be zero. In general, when waves come together, the interference will not be completely constructive or completely destructive but somewhere in between.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Wave x plus wave y equals resultant wave z with increased amplitude to demonstrate constructive interference and then destructive interference where the waves are completely canceled out
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Wave x plus wave y equals resultant wave z with increased amplitude to demonstrate constructive interference and then destructive interference where the waves are completely canceled out

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Reflection of waves</button>: Consider a pulse (or a <button class='glossary-text'>periodic</button> wave) traveling down a cord. When the pulse reaches the end of the cord, it will be reflected back along the cord. The reflection will have a phase shift of 180 degrees if the end of the cord is fixed (it will be inverted) and no phase change if the end is free (see Figure 3).

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Wave A traveling to a fixed boundary, reflecting and inverted, and Wave B traveling to a free boundary, reflecting and unchanged
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Wave A traveling to a fixed boundary, reflecting and inverted, and Wave B traveling to a free boundary, reflecting and unchanged

pageData.text: If the pulse is traveling along one cord tied to another cord with a different density, some of the energy will be transmitted into the second cord and some will be reflected. For a pulse going from a lighter cord (lower density) to a heavier cord (higher density), the reflection occurs as if the end is a fixed boundary. If the pulse travels from a higher density (heavier) cord to a lower density (lighter) cord, the reflection will be the same as if the end was a free boundary.

pageData.subTitle: Standing Waves on a String
pageData.text: Consider waves or pulses moving along a cord or string fixed at both ends, similar to a stringed instrument like a guitar. When a pulse (or part of a wave) reaches one of the fixed ends of the string, it will be inverted and reflected back. This reflected pulse will interfere with part of the wave still moving toward the fixed end. Typically, the interference will be neither completely constructive nor completely destructive. In special cases, when the <button class='glossary-text'>wavelength</button> is matched to the length of the string, the result can be standing waves.

When the proper conditions are met, the interference between two equal waves traveling in opposite directions will cause the string to oscillate in segments or loops. Adjusting tension and length of the string so the two oppositely directed waves superimpose creates areas of maximum <button class='glossary-text'>amplitude</button> called antinodes and points with zero amplitude or no vibration called nodes. The establishment of a standing wave corresponds to resonant vibrations of the string (see Figure 4). Mechanical resonance occurs when a system is forced to vibrate at the same <button class='glossary-text'>frequency</button> as the system’s natural frequency.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Standing waves on a string showing the decrease in wavelength from the fundamental harmonic, lambda sub 1 equals 2 L, through the fifth harmonic, lambda sub 5 equals begin fraction 2 over 5 end fraction L
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Standing waves on a string showing the decrease in wavelength from the fundamental harmonic, lambda sub 1 equals 2 L, through the fifth harmonic, lambda sub 5 equals begin fraction 2 over 5 end fraction L

pageData.text: The length of a string fixed at both ends limits the possible that can be established on the string. The velocity, v, of a wave on a stretched string is given by Equation 3 where T is the tension (stretching force) and μ is the mass per unit length of the string.

pageData.desc: Equation 3: v equals begin square root begin fraction T over mu end fraction end square root
pageData.altText: Equation 3: v equals begin square root begin fraction T over mu end fraction end square root

pageData.text: The possible frequencies are determined using : v = fλ (SI unit m/s).

The lowest frequency is called the fundamental frequency, or first harmonic, occurring when the length of the string, L, is equal to half of a wavelength, or λ = 2L. For a stretched string, higher frequencies are multiples of the fundamental frequency and are referred to as higher harmonics. The general equation relating the string length, L, to the wavelength, λ, is shown in equation 4.

pageData.desc: Equation 4: Begin equation L equals begin fraction n lambda over 2 end fraction end equation n equals 1, 2, 3, 4, ellipses n
pageData.altText: Equation 4: Begin equation L equals begin fraction n lambda over 2 end fraction end equation n equals 1, 2, 3, 4, ellipses n

pageData.text: where n represents the harmonic, n = 1 is the first harmonic, n = 2 is the second harmonic, n = 3 is the third harmonic, etc.
The frequencies of these harmonics can be determined by solving Equation 4 for the and substituting the relationship into .

pageData.desc: equation Lambda equals begin fraction 2 L over n end fraction
pageData.altText: equation Lambda equals begin fraction 2 L over n end fraction

pageData.desc: Equation 5: Begin equation f equals begin fraction v over lambda end fraction equals begin fraction v over begin fraction 2 L over n end fractions equals begin fraction n v over 2 L end fraction end equation n equals 1, 2, 3, 4, ellipses n
pageData.altText: Equation 5: Begin equation f equals begin fraction v over lambda end fraction equals begin fraction v over begin fraction 2 L over n end fractions equals begin fraction n v over 2 L end fraction end equation n equals 1, 2, 3, 4, ellipses n

pageData.text: Substitute into Equation 5 the velocity, v, relationship from to provide a relationship between the frequencies, the tension on the string, T, and the mass per unit length of the string, μ.

pageData.desc: Equation 6: Begin equation f equals begin fraction n v over 2 L end fraction equals begin fraction n begin square root begin fraction T over mu end fraction end square root over 2 L end fraction equals begin fraction n over 2 L end fraction begin square root begin fraction T over mu end fraction end square root end equation  n equals 1, 2, 3, 4, ellipses n
pageData.altText: Equation 6: Begin equation f equals begin fraction n v over 2 L end fraction equals begin fraction n begin square root begin fraction T over mu end fraction end square root over 2 L end fraction equals begin fraction n over 2 L end fraction begin square root begin fraction T over mu end fraction end square root end equation  n equals 1, 2, 3, 4, ellipses n

pageData.text: The frequencies of standing waves established on a stretched string of a fixed length, L, can be calculated if the tension on the string, T, and the mass per unit length, μ, is known. In the Standing Waves on a String lab, you will create the conditions for establishing standing waves on different types of string and observe various standing waves on a string.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for the investigation. To prepare, calculate mass/unit length of the stings, assemble the pulley clamp system, calculate the tension on the string and measure the length of the sting in the pulley. In activity 1, pluck the string, record it and obtain an image of a standing wave.  Then, determine the length of a loop of the standing wave. Next, measure the mass of additional washers and add them to the string. Then, calculate the tension on the string and repeat this for 4 trials. Next, set up the pulley clamp system with a new string and repeat the procedure for all 3 strings. In activity 2, calculate the velocity and wavelength for each trial. Then, calculate the average wavelength, the frequency and graph velocity versus frequency for each string.  In the extension activity, calculate the parameters for the given number of loops. Then, calculate the average frequency and graph the velocity versus wavelength. Finally, repeat this for all 3 strings.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the Standing Waves on a String investigation (item number 580262) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company. Call: 866.332.4478 to order.

Read all the instructions for this activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this investigation. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after the investigation, and clean the work area with soap and water after finishing. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: A violin string is plucked.  Standing waves with the following four frequencies vibrate on the string: 90 Hz, 180 Hz, 270 Hz, 540 Hz.  Which frequency corresponds to the standing wave with the greatest number of nodes?

options.text: They all have the same number of nodes.

assestmentData.question: A violin string is plucked.  Standing waves with the following four frequencies vibrate on the string: 90 Hz, 180 Hz, 270 Hz, 540 Hz.  Which frequency corresponds to the standing wave with the least number of nodes?

options.text: They all have the same number of nodes.

assestmentData.question: Greater sound energy forms larger waves.  Larger waves have which of the following?
What is the term for points along a standing wave where the wave has minimum (zero) amplitude?
What is the term for points along a standing wave where the wave has maximum amplitude?
The separation between adjacent nodes of standing waves for a given λ is which of the following?
If a vibrating body is to be in resonance as a result of a driving force, the frequency of the driving force must be_____________

options.text: the same as the natural frequency of the vibrating body.
vibrating more slowly than the vibrating body.
vibrating faster than the vibrating body.
vibrating with the greatest possible amplitude.
vibrating with the least possible amplitude.

assestmentData.question: What type of wave has vibrations parallel to the wave’s direction of propagation?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Create a work space; you will be setting up the lab apparatus on a table or desk. If possible, use a table or desk with a width of >50 cm but <100 cm (between 0.50 m and 1.00 m wide).
Read through the activities.

Obtain the required materials. The additional types of string/twine should have thicknesses greater than the string provided in the materials kit. This will ensure you are able to determine the mass per unit length for the additional string/twine.

Measure out 2.5 m of the String 1 (the string provided in the lab kit). Bunch the string up, and place it on the electronic balance to determine the mass of the string. Be sure the balance is zeroed. If the mass of the string does not register on the balance, add additional string until you are able to get a mass reading. Record the mass and length of String 1 in Data Table 1 of the Lab Notebook.
Identify your other two types of string as String 2 and String 3. The strings should be identified in order of thickness: String 2 thinner than String 3.

Repeat Step 4 for your two additional types of string/twine, recording the mass and length values in Data Table 2 and Data Table 3, respectively. Since Strings 2 and 3 have a greater thickness than String 1, you will need less string to get a reading on the electronic balance. Test for the length of string you need by unwinding a length of string (but not cutting it off) and placing it on the balance. Adjust the length of string until you get a mass value on the balance, then cut off the string and measure its length. For example, 135 cm of a certain type of nylon cord had a mass of 1.0 g.
Calculate the mass per unit length of each type of string. Record these values in Data Tables 1, 2, and 3, respectively, using the SI unit of kg/m.

Tie a loop in one end of String 1. Place this loop over the winged screw handle part of one of the clamps so the loop is between the winged screw handle and the bottom of the clamp (see Figure 5). When the screw is tightened, the loop should remain around the screw. Extend the string over the pulley. When the string is in place, the clamp is ready to be attached to the table or desk. Attach this clamp so the string can be stretched across the narrowest part of the table or desk.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: A string loop attached to the screw on the clamp below the winged handle, with the string then fed through the clamp’s pulley
pageData.altText: Figure 5: A string loop attached to the screw on the clamp below the winged handle, with the string then fed through the clamp’s pulley

pageData.text: Attach the other clamp to the other side of the narrowest part of the table or desk so that it is aligned with the first clamp.

Pull the string looped around the clamp screw up and over the pulley of the clamp, and stretch it across the table or desk to the pulley on the clamp on the opposite side. Place the string around the pulley, and let approximately 40 cm of the string hang down below the clamp (see Figure 6). Cut off the remaining string, and tie a loop in this end of the string. The length of the string shown in Figure 6 from the top of one pulley to the top of the other pulley is 63 cm. The view shown in Figure 6 is the preferred viewpoint for observing the vibration of the string. In Figure 6, a large cardboard box has been placed behind the string to create a solid background for viewing the vibrations of the string.

pageData.desc: Figure 6: A string attached to clamp on the left, running through that clamp’s pulley, across a table, and through another clamp’s pulley on the right
pageData.altText: Figure 6: A string attached to clamp on the left, running through that clamp’s pulley, across a table, and through another clamp’s pulley on the right

pageData.text: Fashion a mass hanger out of one of the paper clips. (A second or third paper clip mass hanger may be needed to hold all the washers.) The weight of the washers will put tension on the string.

Use the electronic balance to determine the total mass of 4 washers. Record this value in Data Table 1 for Trial 1 using SI units of kg. If you keep track of these washers and use the same 4 washers for each Trial 1, you can record the mass of the 4 washers in the appropriate columns of Data Tables 2 and 3.

Calculate the tension on the string, and record this value in Data Table 1. Record the tension in Data Tables 2 and 3 if you are using the same washers. The tension, in newtons, is equal to the weight of the hanging mass, mg, where g is 9.80 m/s2.
Place the paper clip mass hanger on the loop at the free end of the string. Place the 4 washers on the paper clip. This will tighten the string.

Measure the length of the string from the top/middle of one pulley to the top/middle of the other pulley, where the string is no longer contacting the pulley. Record this value as the length of the string in Data Tables 1, 2, and 3 using SI units of meters, m.

In Activity 1, you will set up a pulley clamp system with washers to provide tension on the string. You will then pluck the string to create standing waves and measure the resulting loop lengths. You will vary the mass of washers providing tension and the thickness of the spring.  You will analyze this data in Activity 2.

typeBefore.text: Note: Record measurements and make calculations using SI units with the correct number of significant digits.
For this part of the lab you will create, observe, and measure the length of standing waves on String 1.

pageData.text: You will be plucking the string to start it vibrating and recording the motion for review. Set up to record so you view the string from the edge of the table or desk (see Figure 7), then watch this video demonstration.

pageData.desc: Figure 7: View of setup, looking horizontally at the table at eye level with the pulleys on either end
pageData.altText: Figure 7: View of setup, looking horizontally at the table at eye level with the pulleys on either end

pageData.desc: How to Pluck a string and observe its vibrations
camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Start the video recording. Pluck the string by pulling up on it and quickly releasing it. Pluck the string 3 more times before stopping the recording. This should ensure you have a good image of a standing wave.

Playback the video to observe your standing wave. You will need to pause the recording and advance it manually until you get to a view that shows the establishment of the standing wave on the string. If you do not observe a standing wave, or loop, on your string, repeat this trial.
pageData.desc: record a video symbol
pageData.altText: record a video symbol

pageData.text: Measure the length of the loop of the standing wave, and record this value in Data Table 1. If you observe more than one wave loop on the string, make the appropriate measurements to determine the (see ) and note this in your data table.

If the wave loop does not extend the full length of the string, use the scale of your recording to determine the length of the loop. Measure the total length of the string as it appears on your video screen. (Use the same points you used when measuring the length of the string, pulley to pulley.) Then create a ratio using the actual length of the string and the total length of the string as it appears on the screen. For example, if the actual length of a string is 0.63 m and the same length of string on the screen is 0.30 m, the ratio for determining length would be (0.63/0.30). If a wave loop, as measured on the screen is 0.22 m, then the length to be recorded would be (0.63/0.30) × 0.22 m = 0.462 m. This means if you were able to measure the length of the loop without the aid of a video recording, you would measure the length of the loop as 0.462 m.

Use the electronic balance to determine the total mass of 4 more of the washers. Add the mass of the 4 additional washers to the mass of the 4 washers from Trial 1. Record this mass value in Data Table 1 for the 8-washer trial using SI units of kg. If you keep track of these washers and use the same 4 additional washers for each Trial 2, you can record the total mass of the 8 washers in the appropriate columns of Data Table 2 and 3.

Calculate the tension on the string, and record this value in Data Table 1 for Trial 2. Record the tension in Data Table 2 and 3 if you are using the same washers. The tension, in newtons, is equal to the weight of the hanging mass, mg, where g is 9.80 m/s2.
Place the additional 4 washers on the paper clip hanger on the loop of string.
Repeat Steps 2 through 4.

Use the electronic balance to determine the total mass of 4 more of the washers. Add the mass of the 4 additional washers to the mass of the 8 washers from Trial 2. Record this mass value in Data Table 1 for the 12-washer trial using SI units of kg. If you keep track of these washers and use the same 4 additional washers for each Trial 3, you can record the total mass of the 12 washers in the appropriate columns of Data Table 2 and 3.

Calculate the tension on the string, and record this value in Data Table 1 for Trial 3. Record this tension in Data Table 2 and 3 if you are using the same washers. The tension, in newtons, is equal to the weight of the hanging mass, mg, where g is 9.80 m/s2.
Place the additional 4 washers on the paper clip hanger on the loop of string. You may need an additional paper clip hanger to hold all 12 washers.
Repeat Steps 2 through 4.

Use the electronic balance to determine the total mass of 4 more of the washers. Add the mass of the 4 additional washers to the mass of the 12 washers from Trial 3. Record this mass value in Data Table 1, 2, and 3 for the 16-washer trial using SI units of kg.
Calculate the tension on the string, and record this value in Data Table 1, 2, and 3 for Trial 4. The tension, in newtons, is equal to the weight of the hanging mass, mg, where g is 9.80 m/s2.
Place the additional 4 washers on the paper clip hanger on the loop of string. You may need an additional paper clip hanger to hold all 16 washers.
Repeat Steps 2 through 4.
Remove the washers and paper clips from the string (keeping track of your sets of 4 washers). Remove the string from the pulleys.

typeBefore.text: For this part of the lab you will create, observe, and measure the length of standing waves on String 2.

pageData.text: Tie a loop in one end of the second string, and place this loop over the screw part of one of the clamps. The loop of string should be made large enough to go over the winged handle without removing the clamp from the table or desk.

Pull the string looped around the clamp screw up and over the pulley of the clamp. Stretch it across the table or desk to the pulley on the clamp on the opposite side. Let approximately 40 cm of the string hang down below the clamp. Cut off any additional string, then tie a loop at the end of the string.
Place a paper clip hanger on the loop at the free end of the string. Place the first 4 washers on the paper clip.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Start the video recording. Pluck the string by pulling up on it and quickly releasing it. Pluck the string 3 more times before stopping the recording. This should ensure you have a good image of a standing wave.

Playback the video to observe your standing wave. You will need to pause the recording and advance it manually until you get to a view that shows the establishment of a standing wave on the string. If you do not observe a standing wave, or loop, on your string, repeat this trial.
pageData.desc: record a video symbol
pageData.altText: record a video symbol

pageData.text: Measure the length of the loop of the standing wave, and record this value in Data Table 2. If the wave loop does not extend the full length of the string, use the scale of your recording determined in Part A. If you observe more than one wave loop on the string, make the appropriate measurements to determine the (see ) and note this in your data table.
Place the second set of 4 (additional) washers on the paper clip hanger on the loop of string.
Repeat Steps 4 through 6.
Place the third set of 4 (additional) washers on the paper clip hanger on the loop of string. You may need an additional paper clip hanger to hold all 12 washers.
Repeat Steps 4 through 6.
Place the fourth set of 4 (additional) washers on the paper clip hanger on the loop of string. You may need an additional paper clip hanger to hold all 16 washers.
Repeat Steps 4 through 6.
Remove the washers and paper clips from the string (keeping track of your sets of 4 washers). Remove the string from the pulleys.

typeBefore.text: For this part of the lab you will create, observe, and measure the length of standing waves on String 3.

pageData.text: Tie a loop in one end of the third string, and place this loop over the screw part of one of the clamps. The loop of string should be made large enough to go over the winged handle without removing the clamp from the table or desk.

Pull the string looped around the clamp screw up and over the pulley of the clamp. Stretch it across the table or desk to the pulley on the clamp on the opposite side. Let approximately 40 cm of the string hang down below the clamp. Cut off any additional string, then tie a loop at the end of the string.
Place a paper clip hanger on the loop, at the free end of the string. Place the first 4 washers on the paper clip.

pageData.text: Measure the length of the loop of the standing wave, and record this value in Data Table 3. If the loop does not extend the full length of the string, use the scale of your recording determined in Part A. If you observe more than one wave loop on the string, make the appropriate measurements to determine the wavelength (see Figure 4) and note this in your data table.
Place the second set of 4 (additional) washers on the paper clip hanger on the loop of string.
Repeat Steps 4 through 6.
Place the third set of 4 (additional) washers on the paper clip hanger on the loop of string. You may need an additional paper clip hanger to hold all 12 washers.
Repeat Steps 4 through 6.
Place the fourth set of 4 (additional) washers on the paper clip hanger on the loop of string. You may need an additional paper clip hanger to hold all 16 washers.
Repeat Steps 4 through 6.
Remove the washers and paper clips from the string, remove the string from the pulleys, and remove the clamps from the table or desk.
Clean your work space.

In Activity 2, you will analyze the data in Activity 1 to determine the velocity, <button class='glossary-text'>wavelength</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>frequency</button> for the strings at different tensions. You will then graph velocity versus frequency for each string.
Calculate the velocity for each trial in Data Tables 1, 2, and 3 using Equation 3. Record these values in the appropriate columns of the data tables.

Calculate the average wavelength of the set of 4 trials in each of the Data Tables 1, 2, and 3. Record the values in the appropriate space in each data table.
Calculate the of the standing waves for each of the trials in Data Tables 1, 2, and 3 using Equation 2. Record these frequencies in the appropriate columns of the data tables.

pageData.text: Use a graphing program such as Excel or Google Sheets to create a graph using the data from Data Table 1 for velocity, v, vs. frequency, f. (Note: variables are identified for graphing as y vs. x.) On the graph, insert a best-fit line and display the equation. Title the graph, and label the axes with quantity and units. Consider whether the data point (0, 0) should be included on your graph; include the point (0, 0) if it is in agreement with the experiment and relationships between the variables.

In the Extension Activity, you will analyze data for strings with given mass per unit lengths. You will use the data to graph the velocity versus <button class='glossary-text'>wavelength</button> for each of the given strings.

Establishing Standing Waves on a StringOutcomes
  • Investigate the relationships between the parameters for standing waves on a string with harmonic ≥ 1.
  • Calculate tension (T), velocity (v), wavelength (λ), and (f) for standing waves on strings with different mass-per-unit-length values.
  • Determine the relationship between frequency and mass per unit length when standing waves are established on strings with different mass per unit lengths.
  • Determine the relationship for standing waves on a string between wavelength and the tension applied to the string.
Materials Needed but not supplied:
  • Calculator
  • Graphing program such as Excel or Google Sheets

typeBefore.text: One method of creating standing waves on a string with higher order harmonics (>1) requires vibrating the string at a fixed (known) <button class='glossary-text'>frequency</button> while adjusting the tension on the string until the desired harmonic is observed. Another method is to apply a fixed (known) tension to the string and varying the frequency until the different harmonics are observed. For either method, the cost of the equipment that would be required is prohibitive; therefore, in the extension activity, experimental data is provided.

Data Tables E1, E2, and E3 in the Lab Notebook contain data that was collected for three strings with different mass per unit lengths. The experimental setup for collecting this data used a fixed frequency to vibrate the string. The tension on the string was varied to create standing waves with different numbers of loops corresponding to different harmonics. Your analysis of the data will allow you to determine the value of the fixed frequency at which the strings were vibrated.
For the extension activity, you will perform calculations to determine the parameters of standing waves on different strings.

pageData.text: Calculate the tension (T), velocity (v), (λ), and frequency (f) for the number of loops indicated in Data Table E1 using the mass per unit length μ = 1.355 × 10−4 kg/m.
Calculate the average of the frequencies in Data Table E1, and record this value in the appropriate space in Data Table E1.

Use a graphing program such as Excel or Google Sheets to create a graph using the data in Data Table E1 of velocity, v, vs. wavelength, λ (v vs. λ). (Note: variables are identified for graphing as y vs. x.) On the graph, insert a best-fit line and display the equation on the graph. Title the graph, and label the axis with quantity and units. Consider whether the data point (0, 0) should be included on your graph; include the point (0, 0) if it is in agreement with the experiment and relationships between the variables.

Use a graphing program such as Excel or Google Sheets to create a graph using the data in Data Table E2 of velocity, v, vs. wavelength, λ (v vs. λ). (Note: variables are identified for graphing as y vs. x.) On the graph, insert a best-fit line and display the equation. Title the graph, and label the axes with quantity and units. Consider whether the data point (0, 0) should be included on your graph; include the point (0, 0) if it is in agreement with the experiment and relationships between the variables.
Calculate the tension (T), velocity (v), wavelength (λ), and frequency (f) for the number of loops indicated in Data Table E3 using mass per unit length μ = 3.313 x 10−4 kg/m.
Calculate the average of the frequencies in Data Table E3, and record this value in the appropriate space in Data Table E3.

Use a graphing program such as Excel or Google Sheets to create a graph using the data in Data Table E3 of velocity, v, vs. wavelength, λ (v vs. λ). (Note: variables are identified for graphing as y vs. x.) On the graph, insert a best-fit line and display the equation. Title the graph, and label the axes with quantity and units. Consider whether the data point (0, 0) should be included on your graph; include the point (0, 0) if it is in agreement with the experiment and relationships between the variables.

text: Did you observe any standing waves consisting of more than one loop?  If so, describe the circumstances that established the wave, i.e., type of string light/heavy, hanging mass least/greatest.  If you did not observe standing waves consisting of more than one loop, describe the circumstances you think would have established the wave, i.e., lighter/heavier string, less/more tension.

The slope of a graph of velocity vs frequency is equal to the wavelength.  Compare the slope of your Data Table graphs to the average wavelength calculated in your Data Tables by calculating the percent difference.

For difficult measurements an error of 10% or less is acceptable.  For most experiments an acceptable error is 5% or less.  Reflecting on the lab, is the percent difference calculated within an acceptable percent error?  Explain why or why not.

text: The slope of the line in your Extension Activity Graphs is the experimental fixed frequency value used to establish standing waves on the strong with a mass per unit length m=1.355 x 10<sup>-4</sup> kg/m.  Calculate the percent difference between the slope of your line and the average frequency calculated for each Extension Activity Data Table.
For most experiments an acceptable error is 5% or less; is the percent difference calculated for the frequency in each Extension Activity Data Table within an acceptable percent error?

Review the frequency values in Extension Activity Data Tables 1, 2, and 3.  Investigate if there is a relationship between frequency and mass per unit length.  Describe how the frequency is affected as the mass per unit length increases.

Review the tension values in Extension Activity Data Tables 1,2, and 3.  Investigate the relationship between the tension and the wavelengths of the waves on the string.  Describe how the wavelength is affected as the tension applied to the sting increases.
Establish a mathematical relationship that explains why the hanging mass increases as the number of loops on the string decreases.  Refer to Equations 2, 3, and 4 to support your answer.

A map of the procedural workflow for the investigation. To prepare, calculate mass/unit length of the stings, assemble the pulley clamp system, calculate the tension on the string and measure the length of the sting in the pulley. In activity 1, pluck the string, record it and obtain an image of a standing wave.  Then, determine the length of a loop of the standing wave. Next, measure the mass of additional washers and add them to the string. Then, calculate the tension on the string and repeat this for 4 trials. Next, set up the pulley clamp system with a new string and repeat the procedure for all 3 strings. In activity 2, calculate the velocity and wavelength for each trial. Then, calculate the average wavelength, the frequency and graph velocity versus frequency for each string.  In the extension activity, calculate the parameters for the given number of loops. Then, calculate the average frequency and graph the velocity versus wavelength. Finally, repeat this for all 3 strings.

pageData.content: How to Pluck a String and Observe Its Vibrations

data.title: Amplitude
data.content: The height of the wave above equilibrium (to the crest) or below equilibrium (to a trough)

data.title: Constructive interference
data.content: If two waves are in phase, their oscillations result in an amplitude that is larger than the individual waves

data.title: Destructive interference
data.content: Occurs when two waves are out of phase and cancel each other out

data.title: Electromagnetic wave
data.content: A wave that can travel through a vacuum or outer space

data.title: Frequency
data.content: The number of oscillations or cycles per unit time

data.title: Longitudinal wave
data.content: A wave in which the displacement of the particles in the medium moves parallel to the direction of propagation

data.title: Mechanical wave
data.content: A wave that requires the presence of a material medium to transport its energy from one location to another

data.title: Period
data.content: The time it takes for one complete oscillation of the wave to travel past a point in the medium

data.title: Principle of linear superposition
data.content: When two or more waves occupy the same space at the same time

data.title: Speed
data.content: The speed of the wave through a medium; it is the product of the frequency and the wavelength

data.title: Transverse wave
data.content: A wave in which the displacement of the particles of the medium moves perpendicular to the direction of propagation

data.title: Wavelength
data.content: The distance between two corresponding parts of the wave
